1.subject: Action Required: Update Your Direct Deposit Info
1.body:
Dear Employee,

We are switching to a new payroll system for the upcoming month.

Please click here to confirm your direct deposit details immediately to ensure you get paid on time.

Failure to update your information by 5:00 PM today will result in a delay in your paycheck.


Regards,
Human Resources Team
1.explanation: Phishing! Look at the urgency ('Failure to update... delay in paycheck') and the generic greeting ('Dear Employee'). Also, HR would rarely ask for sensitive banking changes via a link in an unsolicited email.

2.subject: New sign-in to your account
2.body:
Hi John,

We noticed a new sign-in to your Netflix account from a device in Moscow, Russia.

If this was you, you can ignore this email.

If this wasn't you, please reset your password immediately to secure your account.


The Netflix Team
2.explanation: Safe. This is a standard security alert. It addresses the user by name (if known) and doesn't demand immediate clicking of a masked link. It alerts you to activity but doesn't threaten you.

3.subject: Urgent Wire Transfer Request
3.body:
Hey,

I'm in a meeting right now and can't talk, but I need you to process a wire transfer for a new vendor ASAP.

It's very time-sensitive. I will send the invoice details in the next email.

Please confirm you received this.


Sent from my iPhone
3.explanation: Phishing (Whaling)! Check the sender email. The CEO wouldn't use a personal Gmail account for official wire transfers. The request bypasses standard procedures and relies on urgency and authority.

4.subject: Scheduled Maintenance Notification
4.body:
Team,

We will be performing scheduled maintenance on the file servers this Saturday from 10:00 PM to 2:00 AM.

Services may be intermittent during this time. No action is required from you.


IT Support
4.explanation: Safe. This is an informational email. It does not ask you to click a link, download an attachment, or provide a password.

5.subject: Failed Delivery Attempt: #839201
5.body:
We tried to deliver your package today but no one was home.

To reschedule delivery, please pay the $1.99 redelivery fee via the link below.

Click here to pay and reschedule


Thank you for shopping with us.
5.explanation: Phishing! Look at the domain 'amzon-logistics-support.net' - that is NOT Amazon. Also, asking for a small fee for redelivery is a common scam to steal credit card numbers.

phishing.title: Phishing Attacks
phishing.description: Master the art of spotting digital deception and email fraud.
phishing.content:
The Anatomy of a Phish

Phishing isn't just about bad grammar anymore. Modern attacks are sophisticated, often using "Spear Phishing" tactics where the attacker researches you specifically before sending the email.

Types of Phishing

  • Spear Phishing: Targeted at a specific individual using real details (e.g., mentioning your boss's name).
  • Whaling: Targeting high-profile executives (CEOs, CFOs) to authorize massive financial transfers.
  • Clone Phishing: The attacker copies a legitimate email you previously received but swaps the link for a malicious one.

üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è The Red Flag Checklist

Before clicking, perform these checks:

  • The "From" Domain: Is it support{'@'}netflix.com or support{'@'}netflix-security-update.com? Look for subtle misspellings (Typosquatting) like rnicrosoft.com (r+n looks like m).
  • Emotional Triggers: Fear ("Your account is banned"), Greed ("You won an iPhone"), or Curiosity ("Look at these photos of you") are used to bypass your critical thinking.
  • The Hover Test: On desktop, hover your mouse over the button. Does the preview URL match the text?
üí° Did You Know?
90% of all cyberattacks start with a phishing email. Humans are the "softest" target in any security system.

questions.text: What is the difference between generic Phishing and Spear Phishing?
options: Generic phishing targets everyone; Spear phishing targets a specific person with researched details
Spear phishing is only done via SMS
questions.explanation: Spear phishing is dangerous because it uses personal details (name, job title, hobbies) to make the lie believable.

questions.text: You receive an email from "supprt{'@'}micros0ft.com". What is this technique called?
questions.explanation: Attackers register domains that look visually similar to real ones (using a zero instead of an O) to trick your eyes.

questions.text: What is the safest way to verify a suspicious alert from your bank?
options: Click the link to chat with support
Open a new browser tab and type the bank's URL manually
questions.explanation: Never trust links in the email. Going directly to the website ensures you are on the legitimate platform.

passwords.title: Password & Auth Security
passwords.content:
Why Complexity Matters

While length is important, using a diverse set of characters is a critical component of strong password hygiene. Hackers use sophisticated tools to guess credentials, so reliance on simple words‚Äîeven long ones‚Äîcan leave you vulnerable if the words are in a dictionary.

The Power of Entropy (Randomness)

The most secure passwords combine length with a mix of character types (symbols, numbers, uppercase, and lowercase). A password like Jhk207991{'@'}alg is superior because it disrupts dictionary attacks while maintaining sufficient length to resist brute force.

üõ°Ô∏è The Golden Rules

  • Mix Your Characters: Ensure your password policy includes a full set of characters: uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and symbols.
  • Avoid Reuse: 54% of employees use the same password across multiple platforms. This allows hackers to use a password leaked from one site to unlock your other accounts (Credential Stuffing).
  • MFA / 2FA: Multi-Factor Authentication adds an extra layer of security by verifying the user's identity through a separate device or token, ensuring access is restricted even if the password is compromised[cite: 304].
‚ö†Ô∏è Warning: Never write your passwords down. Research shows 22% of employees still write passwords on paper to remember them, which is a major security risk.

questions.text: According to the research, which password strategy represents good hygiene?
options: Jhk207991{'@'}alg (Long combination with a set of mixed characters)
Writing the password on a sticky note
questions.explanation: Good password hygiene requires "long password combinations" that also comprise a "set of characters" (complexity) to prevent unauthorized access.

questions.text: Why is password reuse considered poor cyber hygiene?
options: It makes the password harder to remember
It causes the password to expire faster
If one site is breached, hackers can access your other accounts (Credential Stuffing)
questions.explanation: Using the same password across platforms is a major issue (practiced by 54% of employees) because a single breach exposes all your accounts.

hygiene.title: Cyber Hygiene
hygiene.description: Daily habits to reduce your digital attack surface.
hygiene.content:
Reduce Your "Attack Surface"

Cyber hygiene isn't just about cleaning screens; it's about minimizing what hackers can exploit. Every app you install is a potential door for a hacker.

The Clean-Up Checklist

  • Software Updates: These aren't just new features; they are often "patches" for security holes found by researchers. Delaying an update leaves the door open.
  • Delete Unused Accounts: That forum you signed up for 5 years ago? If it gets hacked, your email and password might be leaked. Delete old accounts.
  • Backups (3-2-1 Rule):
    • 3 copies of data.
    • 2 different media types (Cloud + Hard Drive).
    • 1 copy offsite (in case of fire/theft).

questions.text: What is the "3-2-1" backup rule?
options: 3 copies of data, 2 different media types, 1 stored offsite
Back up every 3 days at 2 PM
questions.explanation: This ensures that even if your house burns down or you get ransomware, your data survives in the cloud or offsite.

questions.text: Why is "Zero Day" a scary term?
options: It means you have zero days of vacation left
It is a vulnerability known to hackers but the developers have had "zero days" to fix it
It implies the virus lasts zero days
It is a discount day for software
questions.explanation: Zero-day exploits are dangerous because no patch exists yet. Keeping software updated ensures you get the patch as soon as it is released.

social-engineering.title: Social Engineering
social-engineering.description: Hacking the human brain: Vishing, Smishing, and Pretexting.
social-engineering.content:
Hacking Humans, Not Computers

Social engineering is the art of manipulating people so they give up confidential information. Attackers exploit human nature: trust, fear, helpfulness, and curiosity.

The Psychological Triggers

  • Urgency: "Your tax payment is overdue! Pay now or go to jail." (Stops you from thinking logically).
  • Authority: "This is the CEO, I need you to do this favor for me." (Exploits fear of superiors).
  • Reciprocity: An attacker does something nice for you (holds a door, gives a compliment) so you feel obligated to give them info.

Common Techniques

  • Pretexting: Creating a fake scenario (e.g., "I'm from IT support and we need to resync your token").
  • Quid Pro Quo: Offering a service/gift in exchange for information (e.g., "Take this survey for a free iPad").

questions.text: An attacker calls claiming to be IT support and asks for your password to "fix a virus". What is this?
questions.explanation: Real IT support will NEVER ask for your password. They have backend tools to reset it if needed.

questions.text: What is the "Piggybacking" or "Tailgating" attack?
options: Following an authorized person through a secure door without badging in
questions.explanation: Social engineers use "kindness" (asking you to hold the door because their hands are full) to bypass physical security locks.

malware.title: Malware & Ransomware
malware.description: Viruses, Worms, Trojans, and how to stop them.
malware.content:
Know Your Enemy

Malware is an umbrella term for "Malicious Software". It's not just about annoying pop-ups anymore; it's a multi-billion dollar criminal industry.

The Malware Zoo

  • Ransomware: The most dangerous threat today. It encrypts your files (turns them into gibberish) and demands crypto-currency to unlock them.
  • RAT (Remote Access Trojan): Gives the attacker full control of your PC (webcam, microphone, mouse) while you are using it.
  • Keylogger: A silent spy that records every key you press (passwords, credit card numbers) and sends it to the hacker.
  • Botnet: Turns your computer into a "zombie" that attacks other computers without you knowing.
üõë Action Item: If you suspect infection, disconnect from the internet immediately to stop the malware from "phoning home" or spreading to other devices.

questions.text: What is the main goal of Ransomware?
options: To delete your files for fun
To encrypt data and extort money (Crypto) for the decryption key
questions.explanation: Ransomware is a business model. They kidnap your data. Even if you pay, there is no guarantee they will unlock it.

questions.text: How does a "Trojan" malware work?
options: It disguises itself as legitimate software (e.g., a free game or cracked app)
questions.explanation: Named after the Trojan Horse, it tricks the user into installing it willingly by hiding inside something desirable.

mobile-security.title: Mobile Device Security
mobile-security.content:
Your Life in Your Pocket

We treat phones like accessories, but they are powerful computers containing our GPS history, 2FA codes, and banking apps.

Top Mobile Threats

  • Juice Jacking: Public USB charging stations can transfer data. Always use a "Data Blocker" cable or your own power brick at airports.
  • Excessive Permissions: Does a Calculator app need access to your Contacts and Location? No. That's data mining malware.
  • Jailbreaking/Rooting: Removing the safety restrictions of iOS/Android makes you vulnerable. Apps can now escape their "sandbox" and steal data from other apps.
  • Smishing: Phishing via SMS ("Package delivery failed, click here").

questions.text: What is "Juice Jacking"?
options: Stealing data or installing malware via a public USB charging station
questions.explanation: USB cables carry both power and data. Attackers can modify public charging ports to copy your photos while you charge.

questions.text: Why is "Rooting" or "Jailbreaking" a security risk?
options: It removes the OS security sandbox, allowing malicious apps to access sensitive data from other apps
It prevents you from making calls
questions.explanation: The "Sandbox" is what prevents a malicious game from reading your Banking App's memory. Rooting breaks these walls.

physical-security.title: Physical Security
physical-security.description: Clean Desk Policy, Tailgating, and Evil Maids.
physical-security.content:
If they can touch it, they own it.

Software firewalls cannot stop a person who physically walks away with your laptop.

Concepts to Know

  • Tailgating / Piggybacking: Slipping through a secure door when an authorized person opens it. Be the rude person: don't hold the door for strangers!
  • Shoulder Surfing: Spying on screens in trains or cafes. Use a Privacy Filter (a polarized screen protector) so only you can see the display.
  • Clean Desk Policy: Don't write passwords on sticky notes. Don't leave sensitive documents on your desk when you go to the bathroom.
  • Evil Maid Attack: Leaving a device unattended in a hotel room allows an attacker (posing as cleaning staff) to insert a USB drive or tamper with hardware.

questions.text: What is the best defense against "Shoulder Surfing" in public?
questions.explanation: Privacy filters utilize micro-louvers to ensure the screen looks black to anyone not sitting directly in front of it.

questions.text: You are leaving your desk for 2 minutes to get water. What must you do?
options: Ask a neighbor to watch it
questions.explanation: Always lock your session. An unlocked PC allows an attacker to install malware or copy files in under 10 seconds.

usb-security.title: Removable Media Risks
usb-security.description: Rubber Duckies and the danger of "Lost" drives.
usb-security.content:
The Curiosity Trap

USB drives are popular attack vectors because they bypass network firewalls. They are brought inside the building by employees.

The "Rubber Ducky"

A "USB Rubber Ducky" looks like a flash drive, but the computer thinks it's a Keyboard. When plugged in, it types commands at superhuman speed to install viruses, create backdoors, or steal passwords‚Äîall in milliseconds.

Baiting Attacks

Attackers leave USBs labeled "Payroll 2024" or "Confidential" in parking lots. Human curiosity makes us plug it in. Never plug in a found drive.

questions.text: What happens in a "Baiting" attack with a USB drive?
options: The attacker relies on your curiosity to plug the infected drive into a corporate computer
questions.explanation: Social engineering meets hardware. Curiosity kills the cat (and the network security).

questions.text: Why does a computer trust a malicious "Rubber Ducky" USB?
options: It identifies itself as a Keyboard (Human Interface Device), which computers automatically trust
questions.explanation: Computers are designed to accept keyboards immediately. These tools exploit that trust to type malicious commands.

safe-browsing.title: Safe Web Browsing
safe-browsing.content:
The Web is a Minefield

You can get infected just by visiting a website, without clicking anything (Drive-by Download).

Browsing Defense Kit

  • HTTPS (Lock Icon): Encrypts the tunnel between you and the site. NOTE: It does not mean the site is safe, only that the connection is private. Phishing sites use HTTPS too!
  • Ad Blockers (uBlock Origin): Malicious Code is often hidden in advertisements ("Malvertising"). Blocking ads reduces your risk significantly.
  • Pop-ups: Never call the number on a "Your PC is infected" pop-up. It is a scam. Close the browser (Alt+F4).

questions.text: Does the "Lock" icon (HTTPS) mean a website is 100% safe?
options: Yes, it means the site was scanned by Google
No, it only means the connection is encrypted. A phishing site can also have a lock icon
questions.explanation: Attackers can easily get free SSL certificates. HTTPS protects your data in transit, but you might be sending that data securely to a thief.

questions.text: What is "Malvertising"?
options: Injecting malicious code into legitimate advertising networks to infect users who view the ad
questions.explanation: You can be on a reputable news site and get infected because a third-party ad banner contained an exploit kit.

data-privacy.title: Data Privacy & OSINT
data-privacy.content:
You Are The Target

OSINT (Open Source Intelligence) is how hackers build a profile on you using public data.

What are you leaking?

  • Photos of Work: Posting a selfie with your desk in the background? You might be leaking sticky notes with passwords or confidential memos on the screen.
  • Travel Plans: "Flying to Hawaii tomorrow!" = "My house is empty, come rob me."
  • Metadata (EXIF): Photos taken on phones contain GPS coordinates embedded in the file. Sending the raw file reveals exactly where you live.
  • Security Questions: "Happy birthday to my dog, Fluffy!" -> Now the hacker knows the answer to "What is your pet's name?".

questions.text: Why is posting a photo of your Boarding Pass dangerous?
options: The barcode contains your full name, frequent flyer number, and PNR, allowing hackers to cancel or change your flight
questions.explanation: Barcodes on boarding passes hold significant personal data that can be decoded with free phone apps.

questions.text: What is "Doxing"?
options: Compiling and publishing someone's private information (address, phone, employer) online maliciously
questions.explanation: Doxing is used to harass, intimidate, or endanger targets by removing their anonymity.

remote-work.title: Remote Work Security
remote-work.description: VPNs, Home Routers, and Separation of Duties.
remote-work.content:
The Perimeter is Gone

In the office, you are behind a corporate firewall. At home, you are behind a cheap plastic router.

Securing the Home Office

  • VPN (Virtual Private Network): Always use this when working. It creates an encrypted tunnel into the office, protecting your data from your ISP and hackers on the local network.
  • Router Security: Change the default password (admin/admin). Use WPA3 or WPA2 encryption. Update the firmware.
  • Separation: Do not let your kids install games on your work laptop. Do not do personal banking on the work laptop. Keep work and play separate.

questions.text: Why is using public Wi-Fi (cafes/airports) dangerous for work?
options: It is an open network where attackers can perform "Man-in-the-Middle" attacks to intercept data
questions.explanation: On open networks, anyone with simple software can "sniff" the traffic flying through the air around you.

questions.text: What should you do with your home Wi-Fi router?
options: Change the default admin password and keep firmware updated
questions.explanation: Default passwords are public knowledge. Botnets scan for routers that still use "admin/password" to hijack them.

iot-security.title: IoT (Internet of Things)
iot-security.content:
The "S" in IoT stands for Security

(That's a joke‚Äîthere is no S. IoT security is notoriously bad.) Smart fridges, cameras, and lightbulbs often have hard-coded passwords.

The Mirai Botnet

In 2016, a malware named "Mirai" took over thousands of smart cameras and DVRs using default passwords. It used them to launch a massive attack that shut down major parts of the internet.

Defense Strategy: Segmentation

Put your "Smart" devices on a Guest Network. If your cheap smart bulb gets hacked, the attacker is trapped in the Guest network and cannot reach your main laptop or phone.

questions.text: Why are IoT devices (cameras, bulbs) easy targets for hackers?
options: They often have weak default passwords and are rarely updated/patched by users
questions.explanation: Manufacturers prioritize convenience over security. Many devices ship with "admin/admin" and users never change it.

questions.text: What is the best way to protect your home network from insecure IoT devices?
options: Network Segmentation (Put them on a separate Guest Wi-Fi)
questions.explanation: Isolation is key. If a device is compromised, segmentation limits the damage to that specific zone.
